2. The Well of Ananda Bindu Yields Precious Treasures The Well of Ananda Bindu Yields Precious Treasures. Ananda Bindu lived at the foot of Mount Chia-lien.
He was very wealthy with precious treasures.
Merchants from far and near borrowed from him.
Beggars went to him and did not leave empty-handed.
At that time, there were five hundred merchants.
Their ship was wrecked at sea and all their precious treasures were lost.
Few died, and some survived by clinging to planks.
They all went to Ananda Bindu.
The host provided food.
The host drew from the well and obtained precious chests.
Each had a label with their surnames.
The merchants finished eating and all wept.
The host asked the reason.
They replied:
We were traveling with five hundred companions.
Our ship capsized in the ocean.
Few died.
We survived by clinging to small planks.
We grieve for our lost precious treasures and our companions.
Then they saw the precious chests obtained from the well.
All of them are what I have allowed, but I don't know why it is so.
The owner said:
You all go about doing business and trading.ğŸ”½If you are sincere, you will not lose.
It is only because you are not sincere that you lose.
I have been like this since countless eons ago.
I have never been insincere, and I have never deceived or harmed anyone.
All those who have lost treasures should go to my well.
You can each take them away according to your surnames.
Once there was a man named Xianzhi.
He had heard the sutra say that the heavenly eye does not blink and recitation is not forgotten.
However, this Xianzhi.
Was good at stealing other people's things without being noticed.
The king lost a pearl.
He summoned his ministers to discuss it.
The ministers replied to the king, saying:
I have heard that Xianzhi is extremely good at stealing.
The king ordered him to be brought in for questioning, hoping to get a confession that he did not steal.
Since the king has the Way, how could he wrongly accuse someone?
He also summoned his ministers to discuss together.
A minister said:
We should devise a strategy to make him submit.
We should heavily shackle him, parade him through the streets, and proclaim that he is to be executed.
Give him wine to make him drunk, then untie his shackles and place him in the hall, with courtesans providing entertainment.
The king ordered the courtesans:
When Xianzhi is drunk, ask him,
and you can reply:
This is the heavenly realm, and we are heavenly maidens.
You should serve at our side.
In your previous life, you stole the king's pearl, so you were reborn here.
The king then followed their advice.
Xianzhi heard this and silently left, thinking:
I have heard the scriptures say:
The heavenly eyes do not blink, but these women all blink.
Moreover, since I stole the pearl, I should enter hell.
Is it not the case that the king is setting me up to be executed?
He then spoke out:
I was reborn in the heavens because I did not steal the pearl.
The courtesan reported to the king:
Dao Xianzhi said this.
The king then laughed loudly:
The young man definitely did not steal my pearl.
He then released them and let them go.
He bestowed gold and treasures on them again.
This was truly stealing the pearls.
By reciting a single verse, he escaped punishment and received gifts. From the Miscellaneous Parables Sutra.

The consciousness returns to caress the former body's bones. The consciousness returns to caress the former body's bones. In the past, there was a person.
After death, the soul returned to caress the bones of the former body.
People asked him:
You are already dead.
Why do you still use them to caress withered bones?
The spirit said,
This was my former body.
I did not kill, steal, commit adultery, engage in slander, abusive speech, or idle chatter, I was not jealous, angry, or foolish.
After death, I was reborn in the heavens.
My wishes were naturally fulfilled with boundless joy.
Therefore, I cherish it deeply. From the lower fascicle of the Old Miscellaneous Parables Sutra.
The Woodworker and the Painter Deceiving Each Other, Part 7. In the past, in the Northern India,
there was a skilled craftsman.
He made a wooden doll.
It was unparalleled in beauty, with clothes and ornaments no different from a real woman.
It could come and go, serve drinks, and entertain guests.
It could only not speak.
At that time, in the Southern India, there was a painter.
He was also very good at painting.
The craftsman heard about him.ğŸ”½He prepared delicious food and invited the painter.
He then had the wooden doll serve drinks and carry food.
From morning until night.
The painter did not know and thought it was a real woman.
His lustful thoughts were extremely intense and he could not forget her.
It was already evening.
The carpenter entered to stay.
He left the painter to stay.
He left this wooden woman standing by his side.
He said to the guest,
I have left this woman for you to stay with.
The host had already entered.
The wooden woman stood by the lamp.
The guest called out to her.
But the woman did not come.
The guest then went forward to pull her.
Only then did he realize she was wood.
He was ashamed of himself.
The host deceived me.
I will get revenge on him.
Thereupon the painter devised another plan.
He painted his own image on the wall.
The clothes he wore were no different from his body.
He tied a rope around his neck, as if he had hanged himself, and painted the rope image on his mouth.
After finishing, he closed the door and entered under the bed.
At dawn, the host came out and saw that the door was still closed.
He then looked inside.
He only saw the image of the hanged guest on the wall.
The host was terrified and thought it was really dead.
He broke down the door and cut the rope with a knife.
Then the painter came out from under the bed.
The carpenter was greatly ashamed.
The painter said, You were able to deceive me.
I can deceive you too.
The feelings between host and guest are complete, and we do not owe each other anything.
The two people believed and knew that they were deluded.
They each abandoned their loved ones and left home to cultivate the Way. From the fourth fascicle of the Miscellaneous Parables Sutra.

A doctor cured the king's illness and received an extraordinary reward from the king. A doctor cured the king's illness and received an extraordinary reward from the king. There was a king in a country.
His body suffered from a serious illness.
It did not improve for twelve years.
All the great doctors were unable to cure it.
At that time, in a small country on the border that belonged to the great king,
there was a doctor who was good at treating illnesses.
The king immediately summoned him to treat his own illness.
Before long, he was cured.
The king then thought of repaying the teacher's kindness.
The king sent an envoy to proclaim to that country:
This doctor has been appointed. You should repay him with gifts.
Elephants, horses, carriages, cows, sheep, fields, houses, male and female servants, and various ornaments should all be given to him.
The king of the small country received the order and
the doctor was by the king's side, but no one spoke to him.
The doctor then thought to himself:
I have treated the king's illness with great effort.
I do not know if the king will reward me or not.
After several more days, the king gradually recovered.
The doctor took his leave and wished to return to his own country.
The king then allowed it.
He gave him a weak horse and poor riding gear.
The doctor laughed to himself, thinking, I treated the king's illness with great effort.
But the king does not recognize my kindness.
He has not made any arrangements for me.
He is letting me leave empty-handed.
He lamented along the way, thinking it a lasting grievance.
When he arrived back in his own country, he saw a herd of elephants.
He asked the elephant keepers:
Whose elephants are these?
The elephant keepers replied:
This is the elephant of so-and-so's master.
He then asked the elephant calf,
Where did so-and-so's master get this elephant calf?
The calf replied,
So-and-so's master cured the king's illness,
and this is the reward he received.
They went a little further,
and saw many horses, cows, and sheep.
He asked,
Whose are these?
The sheep calf replied,
They belong to so-and-so's master.
They went a little further,

He asked the gatekeeper,

The gatekeeper replied,
This is the house of so-and-so's master.
He then entered the house,
and saw his wife, with a ruddy complexion and wearing jeweled garments.
He wondered and asked,
Whose wife is this?
The gatekeeper replied,
This is the wife of so-and-so's master.
From seeing the elephants and horses,
to entering the house,
he knew that all of this was obtained as a reward for curing the king's illness.
then he will regret his past actions.

Even by breaking the fast, one can still be reborn in the heavens. In the past, there was a gaoseng who
set up a great altar to invite the Buddha and the Sangha.
At that time, there was a person selling yogurt.
The host kept him for a meal.
He encouraged him to observe the fast and listen to the sutra.
He returned home at night.
His wife said to him,
I haven't eaten since this morning, waiting for you until now.
He broke the fast.
Even with half the merit of the fast, one can still be reborn in the heavens for seven lifetimes.
If reborn as a human, one will always obtain natural blessings.
Observing the fast for one day is equivalent to sixty thousand years of natural provisions.
There are also five blessings.
First, few illnesses.
Second, peace of mind and body.
Third, less desire.
Fourth, less sleep.
Fifth, after death, the spirit can be reborn in the heavens and remember past lives. This is taken from the essentials of various sutras.
In the past, there was a man plowing in the fields.
The sun was about to set.
His family had not yet sent him food.
A monk lost his way and came to his field.
He begged for some food.
The farmer said, Yes.
Please wait a little.

The monk said,
Since the food has not arrived, I would like to rinse my mouth.
The farmer untied his clothes and gave him a harÄ«takÄ« fruit.

He also gave the monk a coin as a gift.
The monk said,
If your mind is moved, I will not repay you.
I want to give you the five precepts.
Can you accept them?
He replied,
As a layperson, it is difficult to fully observe the five precepts.

When the farmer's life ended, he was reborn in the royal family of a country.
The empress and her attendants arrived at the riverside.
Singing and dancing, making music, holding the child by the water.
She lost her grip and the child fell into the water, immediately swallowed by a fish.
In the belly for seven days, neither hungry nor thirsty.
Following the current downstream, it went over a thousand li.
Entering the territory of a lower country, people caught the fish and sold it in the market.
At that time, the ruler of the lower country sent someone to buy the fish.
Bringing it back to the city, he used a knife to cut open the fish.
The child in the belly cried out, saying:
Be careful, do not hurt me!
He then cut open the fish's intestines and saw a small child.
Handsome and unparalleled, the entire country rejoiced.
The ruler of the upper country heard about this and said:
This must be my child.
He sent a message requesting it.
The ruler of the lower country replied:
Found in the belly of a fish, a gift from heaven.
I am not willing to give it to you.
The two countries argued together, eventually reaching a great country.
The great king judged, saying:
If the upper country did not give birth to this child, how could it have fallen into the water and been obtained by the lower country?

Your two countries,
in the middle, can build a palace together to accommodate this child.
Call him the Crown Prince of the Two Countries.

In accordance with the rites and laws for a crown prince.
The Buddha said to his disciples:
In the past, a farmer
offered a fruit and a coin to a monk,

The nephew was clever and later obtained the king's daughter as his wife. The uncle and nephew stole together. The nephew was clever and later obtained the king's daughter as his wife. In the past, there were two siblings.
The older sister had a son.
He served in the government office together with his uncle.
They stored in the treasury brocade and silk woven with gold thread, and various precious and wonderful clothes.
They then discussed together,
We have been weaving diligently without slacking off.
We know the good and bad, and the quantity of the items in the treasury.
Should we take some together to relieve our poverty?
At night they dug a hole in the ground and stole the items.
The next morning, the treasury keeper noticed that the items had decreased in quantity.
He reported the matter to the king.
The king ordered that it should not be widely publicized.
He wanted the thieves to think that the king was too busy to notice the theft.
In a few days, they will certainly come again.
Just tighten up the guards and capture them without letting them escape.
The treasury keeper received the order.
He then increased the guards.
After a long time, the thieves came again to steal.
The nephew taught his uncle,
You are old and weak, with little strength.
If you are caught by the guards, you will not be able to escape.
You should go in through the ground hole instead.
If they see you,
I, with my strong strength, will come to rescue you.
The uncle entered the hole and was captured by the guards.
The guards shouted.
The nephew feared being recognized.
He cut off his uncle's head and left.

went to the guard post.

and left.

What should be done about him?
The girl then became pregnant.

He was very handsome.

Why didn't you bind him?
